title: What are the advantages of playing a fretless bass? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll save myself a bit of grief and start with ‘credentials’. I have played bass for over 50 years, most every venue and genre. I have a Kay standup that was purchased when I was born and have owned a wide assortment of electrics over the years including fretless electrics. A fretless instrument has voicing. Like a voice every analog wavelength is available, you must select the right one. There are a few things you can do with a fretless instrument that you can not do at all, or only poorly, with a fretted one. The obvious ones are smooth slides, pitch bends and tremolo. You can even do the bizarre and impossible verses a fretted. Just because it put a smile on our very gifted jazz guitar player every single time, I used to sneak in a five note run from C to D. Those notes would be C, C &1/2, C#, C#&1/2 and D. The tune was 5/4 time and no one but him ever noticed. The very fist time I did that was at practice and he froze, and said “Hey you can’t do that.” My answer was “Wrong, you can’t do that, I can. See.” and played it again. We also played an old tune that started with two beats on Gm, two on B# and kept that up for several bars. I just played a slide between the two notes on my E string. The job of bass is to build a wave and that works like a dream. It also sounds unlike anything you have heard out of a fretted bass. They also sound different for everyone who plays them because they allow for or even exacerbate tiny nuances in fingering. You can pitch a full dime just by rolling your finger a bit. Like singing however these things are only an “advantage” if you also have the ear to apply them correctly. Someone with out a good ear and accurate fretting will sound awful on a fretless and even worse on a bass fiddle. Hope that shed a little light. Thanks for the question.

Mostly it’s because of the tone. You can get a great growl or “mwah” sound from the strings vibrating right on the fingerboard, especially with roundwound strings. Combine that with a good vibrato on your fingering hand and you can get a singing, shimmering sound - very expressive. You can also slide and slur for some interesting effects. You’ll have the ability to get to the “in-between” pitches that you can’t on a fretted bass because the frets force you into regular pitches. You can also do slides with harmonics (play a harmonic then press finger to fingerboard and slide up to another position). Lastly, you can compensate for an out of tune string by playing a little sharp or flat on the fly - useful if you don’t have time to tune up in the middle of a song. Some things you can’t do well on a fretless because of the absence of frets. Anything that needs aggressive fret sound as part of the tone, slapping, and tapping are things that aren’t suitable.
